articles.headline: Israel’s Government Collapses, Setting Up 5th Election in 3 Years
articles.snippet: The governing coalition decided to dissolve Parliament, plunging the country back into paralysis and throwing a political lifeline to Benjamin Netanyahu.
articles.abstract: The governing coalition decided to dissolve Parliament, plunging the country back into paralysis and throwing a political lifeline to Benjamin Netanyahu.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s governing coalition will dissolve Parliament before the end of the month, bringing down the government and sending the country to a fifth election in three years, the prime minister said on Monday.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: After a Pivotal Period in Ukraine, U.S. Officials Predict the War’s Path
articles.snippet: As Russia makes slow but steady progress, the arrival of new weapons systems will help Ukraine hang on to territory, U.S. officials and analysts say.
articles.abstract: As Russia makes slow but steady progress, the arrival of new weapons systems will help Ukraine hang on to territory, U.S. officials and analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Russia shifted its military campaign to focus on eastern Ukraine this spring, senior officials in the Biden administration said the next four to six weeks of fighting would determine the war’s eventual path.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: A Shopping Trip for Apples, Over the Last Bridge in Lysychansk
articles.snippet: Bridges are critical in the battle for Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk, separated by a river. Shelling has mostly destroyed them, but that didn’t stop one woman from walking across to buy some basics.
articles.abstract: Bridges are critical in the battle for Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk, separated by a river. Shelling has mostly destroyed them, but that didn’t stop one woman from walking across to buy some basics.
articles.lead_paragraph: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — The woman’s mission was simple: she was going shopping, and she would not be deterred. Svitlana Zhyvaga just needed to cross a bridge.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

articles.headline: Why You Might Buy Your Next Car Online
articles.snippet: Tesla shifted to selling cars entirely online in 2019. Now, some established automakers, like Ford, are talking about taking a similar approach.
articles.abstract: Tesla shifted to selling cars entirely online in 2019. Now, some established automakers, like Ford, are talking about taking a similar approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2019, many auto experts said Tesla was making a big mistake by deciding to sell cars only online, arguing that whatever bad feelings people had about dealerships they were essential to the car business.

articles.headline: Panel Ties Trump to Fake Elector Plan, Mapping His Attack on Democracy
articles.snippet: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack showed how the former president leaned on state officials to invalidate his defeat, opening them up to violent threats when they refused.
articles.abstract: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack showed how the former president leaned on state officials to invalidate his defeat, opening them up to violent threats when they refused.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack directly tied Donald J. Trump on Tuesday to a scheme to put forward fake slates of pro-Trump electors and presented fresh details on how the former president sought to bully, cajole and bluff his way into invalidating his 2020 defeat in states around the country.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: Supreme Court Rejects Maine’s Ban on Aid to Religious Schools
articles.snippet: The decision was the latest in a series of rulings forbidding the exclusion of religious institutions from government programs.
articles.abstract: The decision was the latest in a series of rulings forbidding the exclusion of religious institutions from government programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that Maine may not exclude religious schools from a state tuition program, the latest decision by a conservative majority that has increasingly favored the role of religion in public life.
